questions.text: An 8-year-old male child presents with fever and tenderness in the left lower limb. The limb is warm to the touch, and ESR is raised. An X-ray reveals periosteal elevation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Osteomyelitis is an infection of the bone, which typically presents with fever, localized pain, warmth, and tenderness. Raised ESR and periosteal elevation on X-ray are classic findings. The history of fever along with these findings makes osteomyelitis the most likely diagnosis in this case.

Investigations of Acute Osteomyelitis

 

  • X-ray
    • Normal during the 1st week.
    • z (periosteal reaction) by 7-10 days.
      • Classical X-ray sign of acute pyogenic osteomyelitis.
    • Later signs
      • Periosteal thickening becomes more obvious.
      • Patchy rarefaction of the metaphysis is observed.
      • Ragged features of bone destruction appear.
    • Important late sign
      • Regional Osteoporosis -metabolically active living bone.
      • The segment that does not become osteoporotic is metabolically inactive and may be dead.

 

Osteomyelitis of the Tibia

 

  • MRI
    • Most sensitive even in the early phase.
    • Detects bone marrow oedema in osteomyelitis within 24 hours
    • The best method of demonstrating bone marrow inflammation.
  • Radio scintigraphy with Gallium citrate - highly sensitive but less specific.
  • SPECT/CT imaging
    • Offers better anatomical localization and a more accurate definition of infection extent compared to conventional planar studies and SPECT alone.
    • It effectively differentiates between soft tissue and bone infections, assesses suspected infected sites with structural bone changes, and clearly defines infective foci in complex anatomical areas.
  • Aspiration of pus-
    • Confirmation of the diagnosis.
    • Aspirate from the metaphyseal subperiosteal abscess, extraosseous soft tissues, or an adjacent joint using a 16- or 18-gauge trocar needle.
    • Even if no pus is present, send a smear of the aspirate for microbiological examination and antibiotic sensitivity testing.

 

Ewing Sarcoma (Option A) is a malignant bone tumor common in children and adolescents. It often presents with pain and swelling, sometimes accompanied by fever

Osteosarcoma (Option B) is a malignant bone tumor that occurs primarily in adolescents. It presents with localized pain and swelling, and X-rays often show a "sunburst" pattern and Codman's triangle.

Giant Cell Tumor (GCT) (Option D) is a benign but locally aggressive bone tumor that typically occurs near the ends of long bones in young adults. It is rare in children and usually does not present with systemic symptoms like fever and periosteal elevation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to the OPD with complaints of pain in the left knee region. He reports that the pain is often worse at night and mentions that he has been taking Aspirin to relieve the pain. An X-ray of the knee is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Osteoid osteoma

Explanation:

Based on the provided X-ray image and the clinical history of a 30-year-old male with night pain relieved by Aspirin, the likely diagnosis is Osteoid Osteoma.

Osteoid Osteoma

A small, benign bone tumor composed of osteoid and woven bone with a surrounding halo of reactive bone

Demographics

Sex: Males > Females

Age: Young patients, but rare under 5 years and over 30.

Location

The diaphysis of long bones, especially the proximal tibia, and femur.

It can also occur in the spine, particularly the posterior arches.

Pathophysiology

The nidus releases prostaglandins which cause the characteristic pain that relieves on taking NSAIDs

Symptoms

Characterized by pain, often worse at night (Night crises), and relieved by NSAIDs (Therapeutic test).

When near joints, it may cause stiffness and effusion.

In the spine, it can lead to muscle spasms and scoliosis.

Radiology

X-Ray:

Dense sclerosis with a small, rounded area of osteolysis, often obscured by the surrounding sclerosis.

The characteristic lesion is less than 1.5 cm in diameter with a sclerotic margin and radiolucent nidus.

 

Isotope bone scans (Best investigation) are positive

Histology

Consists of a mesh of woven bone, osteoblastic rimming, osteoclasts, and dilated capillaries.

The mature osteoid forms the nidus, surrounded by dense, reactive bone and soft tissue with inflammatory changes.

Treatment

CT-guided radiofrequency ablation.

Surgical excision of the nidus (gold standard)

Chondroblastoma (Option A) is a benign tumour affecting the epiphysis. It is usually asymptomatic. X rays show a clear osteolytic lesion in the epiphysis.

Skeletal TB (Option C) also presents with increased pain in the nights, but this patient does not have any other symptoms characteristic of tuberculosis.

Osteosarcoma (Option D) is a malignant bone tumour that affects the metaphysis. X rays show sunburst appearance.

questions.text: What is the most frequent pattern of involvement observed in Pott’s spine?
questions.solution:
Pott's spine, caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis, affects the spine, leading to granulomatous lesions.

  • Paradiscal involvement, the most common pattern, begins at the intervertebral disc, spreading to adjacent vertebrae, potentially causing neurological deficits.
  • Thoraco-lumbar region (D12, L1) is mostly affected, typically in the first three decades of life.
  • Manifestations include bone destruction, cold abscess, and Pott's paraplegia.
  • Spinal TB is usually secondary to pulmonary TB via hematogenous spread.
  • Hematogenous spread occurs through arterial or venous routes, facilitated by subchondral arterial arcade and Batson's venous plexus.
  • Clinical manifestations include a stiff, painful back, rare systemic symptoms, and classical night cries.
  • Deformities include loss of lordosis, followed by gibbus formation, primarily in the thoracic spine.
  • Paraplegia tends to be spastic, especially in the thoracic spine.
  • Imaging modalities include X-ray (loss of plate margins, radiolucency), CT scan (preferred for degeneration assessment), and MRI (best for early diagnosis)

Correct Answer: C) Pin tract infections

Explanation:

  • Ring sequestrum is a type of sequestrum commonly seen in pin tract infections. These infections occur at the site where pins or wires from an external fixator penetrate the skin and bone. The infection can cause the bone to form a "ring-like" sequestrum around the pin, which is a hallmark of pin tract infections.

Types of Sequestrum

Type

Disease

Tubular

Pyogenic

Ring

External Fixator (Pin tract infections)

Black

Actinomycosis

Coralliform

Perthe’s Disease

Coke

Tuberculosis

Sandy

Tuberculosis

Feathery/ Ivory

Syphilis

 

Coke sequestrum Ring sequestrum

 

 

Tubular sequestrum

Incorrect Options:

Fungal infections (Option A) can cause bone involvement (e.g., osteomyelitis), but they typically do not produce a "ring sequestrum" on X-ray. The sequestrum in fungal infections tends to be more irregular and less characteristic than the ring-shaped sequestrum seen in pin tract infections.

Septic arthritis (Option B) is an infection of the joint, not directly involving the bone. While septic arthritis can lead to secondary bone involvement and osteomyelitis (infection of the bone), it is not typically associated with the formation of a "ring sequestrum".

Acute osteomyelitis (Option D) involves a bone infection, usually caused by bacteria, but it typically results in an irregular or amorphous sequestrum. Acute osteomyelitis usually presents with widespread bone destruction, rather than the isolated, ring-shaped sequestrum seen in pin tract infections.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with a gradually progressing swelling and dull aching pain since 6 months in his lower leg .He is otherwise healthy. The  radiographic image of his leg is shown below. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Brodie's Abscess:

Brodie's abscess is a subacute or chronic bone abscess typically caused by Staphylococcus aureus infection. It often presents with localized pain and swelling. Radiographic findings may reveal a well-defined lytic lesion with a sclerotic border.

  • In children Brodie's abscess is most common in the metaphyseal area.
    • Occurs before epiphyseal closure in a child.
  • In adults - more common in epiphysio-metaphyseal junction
    • Occurs after epiphyseal closure in adults.
  • Most common sites - upper tibia, lower femur.
  • Most common organism - Staphylococcus aureus.
  • Most common age - 2nd decade.
  • Pathophysiology - Low virulence of the organism and good host resistance leads to confirming the infection.
    • Cavity is formed.
    • On aspiration sterile pus is seen - due to good host resistance.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Osteosarcoma:

  • Osteosarcoma is a type of malignant bone tumor that commonly affects children and adolescents. It typically presents with pain and swelling, often in the long bones, such as the tibia. Radiographic features may include bone destruction, irregular bone formation, and sunburst appearance.

Option B - Osteoblastoma:

  • Osteoblastoma is a rare benign bone tumor that can cause pain and swelling. It commonly affects the spine and long bones. Radiographic features may show a well-defined, eccentric lytic lesion with variable calcification.

Option D - Ewing's sarcoma:

  • Ewing's sarcoma is a highly malignant bone tumor that primarily affects children and adolescents. It commonly presents with pain, swelling, and a palpable mass. Radiographic features may show a permeative bone destruction, onion skin appearance, and soft tissue involvement.

questions.text: A patient with a history of a road traffic accident 2 years back, and has developed pain and swelling now at the same site. His X-ray image is shown in the image given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Chronic Osteomyelitis:

  • Chronic osteomyelitis is an infection of the bone that persists for an extended period, typically more than six weeks. The infection leads to inflammation, bone destruction, and the formation of dead bone fragments called sequestrum.
  • The X-ray image showing sequestrum and involucrum supports the diagnosis of chronic osteomyelitis. In chronic osteomyelitis, sequestrum refers to the dead bone fragments or necrotic tissue that can be seen as areas of radiolucency on the X-ray. Involucrum, on the other hand, refers to new bone formation surrounding the sequestrum, which appears as a dense, irregularly shaped area on the X-ray.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Osteogenic Sarcoma: Osteogenic sarcoma is a malignant bone tumor that arises from bone-forming cells ,the X-ray findings of sequestrum and involucrum are not typical for osteosarcoma.

Option B - Ewing's Sarcoma: Ewing's sarcoma is malignant bone tumor that often affects children and young adults. It typically presents with a characteristic onion-skin appearance on imaging. The X-ray findings of sequestrum and involucrum are not consistent with Ewing's sarcoma.

Option D - Multiple Myeloma: Multiple myeloma is a malignancy of plasma cells that primarily affects the bone marrow. the X-ray findings of sequestrum and involucrum are not typically associated with multiple myeloma.

questions.text: A patient presents with a ring-shaped (lytic) lesion in the bone. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Brodie's abscess:

Explanation:

Brodie's abscess is a subacute or chronic form of osteomyelitis, a bacterial infection of the bone. It's most commonly found in the metaphysis of long bones, particularly in the tibia.

  • Imaging Features: On an X-ray, it presents as a lytic, ring-shaped lesion surrounded by a thick, reactive sclerotic rim. The central lytic area represents the pus-filled abscess, while the sclerotic rim is new bone formation laid down by the body in response to the chronic infection.
  • Clinical Presentation: Patients, often young adults, may experience localized pain that is worse at night and relieved by non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs).

Incorrect Options:

Simple bone cyst (Option B): This is a benign, fluid-filled lesion that appears as a simple, lucent (lytic) area in the bone, without the characteristic sclerotic rim seen in Brodie's abscess

Aneurysmal bone cyst (Option C): This is a benign, expansile lesion often described as having a "soap bubble" appearance on imaging. It is filled with blood and has a thin shell of bone. It does not typically have the thick, sclerotic rim of a Brodie's abscess.

 

Osteoid osteoma (Option D): This is a benign bone tumor characterized by a small, radiolucent nidus (the actual tumor) surrounded by a large area of reactive cortical sclerosis. While it has a sclerotic component, the central lytic nidus is typically very small and not ring-shaped.

questions.text: De Quervain's tenosynovitis involves the tendons of which muscles ?

choices.text: Extensor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis longus
Extensor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis brevis
Extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis brevis
Extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis longus

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis longus:

  • De Quervain's disease: Inflammation of abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Extensor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis longus: This option is incorrect 

Option B - Extensor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis brevis: This option is incorrect 

Option C - Extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis brevis: This option is incorrect

questions.text: What is the characteristic sign of a simple bone cyst?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Fallen Fragment Sign:

  • The fallen fragment sign refers to a radiographic finding seen in simple bone cysts. It appears as a detached and fallen fragment of bone within the cystic cavity. This sign is considered pathognomonic, meaning it is unique to simple bone cysts and strongly indicative of their presence.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Scalloping of Cortex:

  • Scalloping of the cortex can be observed in various bone lesions, including tumors and cysts. It refers to a concave deformity or erosion of the bone cortex adjacent to the lesion. While scalloping can be seen in simple bone cysts, it is not pathognomonic and can also occur in other conditions.

Option C - Never Breaches Physis: 

  • The physis, or growth plate, is a cartilaginous region at the ends of long bones responsible for bone growth. Simple bone cysts can extend across the physis, breaching its boundaries and causing disruption. Therefore, the statement that simple bone cysts never breach the physis is incorrect.

Option D- Central Radiolucent Lesion: 

  • While simple bone cysts typically appear as central radiolucent lesions on imaging studies, this finding is not specific to simple bone cysts alone. Other bone lesions, such as aneurysmal bone cysts or giant cell tumors, can also present as central radiolucent lesions. Thus, it is not a pathognomonic sign for simple bone cysts.
